STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
April 19, 2021
Susan Mitchell
Samaritas - Southwest
4341 S Westnedge ST 2000
Kalamazoo, MI 49008
RE: License #: CB390258392
Samaritas - Southwest
4341 S Westnedge ST 2000
Kalamazoo, MI 49008
Dear Ms. Mitchell:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on April 16,
2021. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and
Modified Implementation Sustainability, and Exit Plan (MISEP) requirements, a written
corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules
are also violations of the MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15
days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved; this includes identifying
behaviorally specific action steps.
o Repeat violations must include an explanation of why the previous
corrective action plan did not result in compliance.
 Individuals directly responsible for implementing the corrective action step for
each licensing statute and rule, Contract item, DHHS policy or MISEP section
citation, e.g. workers, supervisors, program managers, director, etc.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
implemented and completed.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved; this
includes identifying specific action steps for continuous monitoring.
o MiSACWIS users with access to the Book of Business, InfoView Reports
and the Monthly Child Welfare Management Report should incorporate the
use of these tools as well as other data management reports released by
the Department for continuous monitoring.
 Signature of the responsible party and date.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Claudia Triestram, the area manager at (616) 552-3662.
Sincerely,
Paul Fatato, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
322 E. Stockbridge Ave
Kalamazoo, MI 49001
(269) 251-2471

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12312 Foster parent training.
(2) The foster parent training plan shall provide for all of the
following:
(c) Not less than 6 hours of training annually for each
licensee after the time periods specified in subdivisions (b)
of this subrule.
One of eight open foster home case files reviewed did not have documentation that
the foster parent completed the required number of training hours annually. The
interim report was completed with no documentation of any training hours or a
corrective action plan to correct the issue.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by
another agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record
containing all of the following documents:
(e) A list of all children currently placed in the home.
Two of six borrowed homes reviewed did not have documentation of a list of the
children currently placed in the home.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(7) If any violations are cited and there is a signed
corrective action plan, all social service workers who have
children placed in the home shall be notified there is a
corrective action plan and what is required of the foster
parent in that plan.
One of six special evaluations reviewed did not have documentation of a corrective
action plan in the case file. There was an email documented but the actual corrective
action plan was missing from the case file.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each
child and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and
at least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
4

Three of eight open foster care case files reviewed did not have the Updated Service
Plan completed every 90-days. This involved four of twenty-two USPs; 20, 9, 2, and
1 days late respectively.
This is a repeat violation from the 2020 Renewal Licensing Study Report with
an approved CAP on 5/7/20, a repeat violation from the 2019 Annual Licensing
Study Report with an approved CAP on 5/10/19, a repeat 2018 Renewal
Licensing Study Report with an approved CAP on 5/25/2018, a repeat violation
from the 2017 Annual Licensing Study Report with an approved CAP on
6/1/2017 and a repeat violation from the 2016 Renewal Licensing Study Report
with an approved CAP on 5/18/2016.
R 400.12510 Independent living contract.
(1) There shall be a mutually agreed upon contract between
the youth and the agency specifying all of the following:
(a) The responsibilities of the agency and the youth.
One of six open Independent Living case files reviewed did not have documentation
of the IL contract being completed.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The
facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements except for the
following:
6.16-page 23 Supervisory Oversite (Commitment 66).
Supervisors shall meet at least monthly with each assigned
worker to review the status and progress of each case on
the worker’s caseload. Supervisors shall review and
approve each service plan. The plan can be approved only
after the supervisor has a face-to-face meeting with the
worker, which can be the monthly meeting.
One of eight open foster care case files reviewed did not have documentation that
the supervisor met with the foster care worker each month. This involved one month
missing.
One of six open independent living case files reviewed did not have documentation
that the supervisor met with the case worker each month. This involved one month
missing.
5

3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS Contract/Policy
requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-09C FOSTER CARE ACTION SUMMARY REQUIREMENTS
Page 1-2
The Foster Care/Juvenile Justice (FC/JJ) Action Summary,
DHHS-69 (RFF 69), is used whenever there is “action” on a
case.
Which Cases/When:
All foster care cases where there is:
1. A replacement.
One of eight open foster care case files reviewed had no documentation of the
DHHS-69 for a replacement of a youth in care.
This is a repeat violation from the 2020 Renewal Licensing Study Report with
an approved CAP on 5/7/20. Because of the continued positive improvement
with this licensing rule, they can continue to use the aspects of their past CAP
if they believe it will continue to help with improved compliance.
DHHS Policy Medical Passports
FOM 801 Page
11-13
An updated medical passport is provided to:
• The child’s foster care provider:
At or prior to each placement.
Three of eight open foster care case files reviewed did not have documentation that
the Medical Passport was completed and updated as required. This involved no
Medical Passport documented for a child’s return home and two Medical Passports
not documented for two replacements.
This is a repeat violation from the 2020 Renewal Licensing Study Report with
an approved CAP on 5/7/20.
DHHS Policy Supervisory Approval - USP
FOM 722-09
Page 27
Case service plan approval process requires the foster care
supervisor to:
• Review and approve the USP within 14 calendar days of
the report date.
Three of eight open foster care case files reviewed did not have documentation that
all of the Supervisor approval for Updated Service Plans took place within the
6

required 14-day limit. This involved four of twenty-two USPs, 49, 6, 2, and 1 days
late respectively.
This is a repeat violation from the 2020 Renewal Licensing Study Report with
an approved CAP on 5/7/20, a repeat violation from the 2019 Annual Licensing
Study Report with an approved CAP on 5/10/19 and a repeat 2018 Renewal
Licensing Study Report with an approved CAP on 5/25/2018.
DHHS Policy - Required Participation in Development - Parents and Youth
FOM 722-08C - over 14-Years Old & Foster Parent / Caregiver
Page 2
Upon completion of the parent-agency treatment plan and
service agreement, the parent is given a copy for review. Foster
care workers need to ensure the parent understands all areas
within the agreement. Parents and youths age 14 and older
must sign the PATP. If a parent or youth is unavailable or
refuses to sign the PATP, foster care workers must identify, and
document additional action needed to secure the parent’s
and/or youth’s participation in service planning and compliance
with the PATP. As the goals are achieved, modified or
expanded, the updated PATP will reflect this process. Parents
and youths age 14 and older must participate in the
development of each updated treatment plan, allowing for
opportunity to evaluate their progress towards completing goals.
The individual activities required by the foster parent/caregiver
to meet the specific individual needs of the child placed in their
home are included in the PATP. The foster parent/caregiver
must be included in the PATP process. The foster
parent/caregiver signature is required and indicates that the
foster parent/caregiver acknowledges and agrees to the
activities required to meet the needs of the child in their care.
Additionally, the PATP details the services and activities
provided by the foster care worker to assist the foster
parent/caregiver in caring for the child.
CI 17-096 Treatment Plan Signature Timeframes and
Documentation Requirements
When the treatment plan is completed, signatures for all
appropriate case members must be obtained. Signatures from
all appropriate case members, including youth ages 14 and
older for foster care and youth ages 11 and older for juvenile
justice, should be obtained before the corresponding court
hearing. All treatment plans with a report date of August 1,
2017, or later must have signatures from all appropriate case
members within 30 days of the report date.
7

Five of eight open foster care case files reviewed did not have all of the signatures
on the PATPs documented as required. This involved seven missing parental
signatures, seven missing caregiver signatures, and two missing youth signatures.
There was also, two late parental signatures, two late caregiver signatures, and one
late youth signature.
Three of six open independent living case files reviewed did not have all of the
signatures on the PATPs documented as required. This involved five late youth
signatures and one missing youth signature.
This is a repeat violation from the 2020 Renewal Licensing Study Report with
an approved CAP on 5/7/20, a repeat violation from the 2019 Annual Licensing
Study Report with an approved CAP on 5/10/19 and a repeat 2018 Renewal
Licensing Study Report with an approved CAP on 5/25/2018.
DHHS Policy Family Team Meeting
722-06B page 1-
7
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before
the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/ Disruption At least three business
days prior to a planned change of placement or no later
than three business days after an unplanned placement
change.
Note: Planned and unplanned placement changes include
reunification, placement in a residential setting, step-down
from a residential or hospital setting, return from AWOLP,
or request for change in foster home/relative placements.
8

Seven of eight open foster care case files reviewed did not have documentation that
the Family Team Meetings were completed as required in each of the cases. This
involved five missing FTMs for USPs, two missing FTMs for replacements, and one
FTM that was beyond the 3-day time frame for a replacement.
One of six open independent living case files reviewed did not have documentation
that the Family Team Meeting was completed as required. This involved one missing
FTM for a USP.
This is a repeat violation from the 2020 Renewal Licensing Study Report with
an approved CAP on 5/7/20, a repeat violation from the 2019 Annual Licensing
Study Report with an approved CAP on 5/10/19 and a repeat 2018 Renewal
Licensing Study Report with an approved CAP on 5/25/2018.
DHHS Policy FTM PRACTICE GUIDANCE
722-06B – Page
13
The DHHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report, is used to
capture family demographics, FTM logistical information,
needs, strengths, action steps, safety concerns and the
safety plan, and any recommendations made for the family
during the FTM. The DHHS-1105, FTM Report, must be
completed for every FTM.
Three of eight open foster care case files reviewed did not have documentation that
the DHHS-1105 was completed for each FTM conducted. This involved six missing
DHHS-1105s for the three case files.
One of six open independent living case files reviewed did not have documentation
that the DHHS-1105 was completed as required for each FTM. This involved two
missing DHHS-1105s for two FTMs.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 It was discovered that an annual licensing home study did not have the correct
dates for the period of the report. it appeared that the dates were not changed
from the prior report. The importance of the supervisor checking each aspect of
the report occur.
 It was discovered that the agency was uploading the independent living contracts
in almost all cases but, they were making this document part of the home visit
form. When uploading these documents together they only titled the upload as
the home visit form which made locating the contract very difficult. It was
9

discussed that the contract should be uploaded and titled as a separate
document.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
 It was discussed with the agency the importance of the assessment when
looking at youth for their independent living program. it was suggested that
they seek as much information as possible and request to speak to the
youth’s former placement in an effort to ensure that they are able to identify
the youth’s needs so the treatment plan and focus of support would meet their
needs.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were two substantiated incidents of corporal punishment in care during this
licensing period. These were substantiated by the agency.
The first incident involved a foster parent placing her hands around the child’s neck,
slapping him twice and pushing him to the ground. This special evaluation and
supporting documentation were reviewed and the agency was able to complete an
in-depth and thorough investigation of the allegations. An appropriate corrective
action plan was developed which was completed by the foster parents. The CAP
involved a review of the policy on behavior management and attendance at the
“Nurtured Heart training sessions”. The agency also identified that they would
monitor the progress of the foster parents.
The second incident involved a foster parent spanking the child on clothed buttocks.
This special evaluation and supporting documentation were reviewed and the
agency was able to complete an in-depth and thorough investigation of the
allegations. An appropriate corrective action plan was developed which was
completed by the foster parents. The CAP involved the foster parents completing an
article on corporal punishment and a post test. They also resigned the policy on
discipline and the agency will monitor their progress.
There was one substantiated incident of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period. This was substantiated by the agency only.
This incident involved an adoptive parent making a child smoke seven cigarettes in a
row and then making him eat one. This special evaluation and supporting
documentation were reviewed and the agency was able to complete an in-depth and
thorough investigation of the allegations. The agency recommendation was to
revoke the foster home license. At this time, the recommendation has been sent to
the department for approval.
10

The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period. This CAP was in regards to the 2020
Renewal Licensing Report.
Phone interviews were conducted with various staff, ranging from administration to
direct workers. The direct workers report a belief that they are supported by their
supervisors and the administration. They also report that they have been supplied
the items needed to work in the COVID-19 environment in a safe way. Each worker
reported being able to adjust to the new work environment.
VII. ANALYST REPORT DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
There was one safety alert during this inspection. The field analyst interviewed five
caregivers and two children, while visiting five licensed foster homes and three
relative homes.
Safety Alert
Concern: A smoke alarm in the home was beeping.
Resolution: The agency provided the CWL-4613 which documented that on 4/15/21
they received a video recording of the inside of the home. This recording verified that
the smoke alarm was in working order and not beeping.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on a
regular license.
4/15/2021
________________________________________
Paul Fatato Date
Licensing Consultant
11
